column4: Rubella Post-vaccine: In 1979, 10 years after the MMR vaccine was introduced, just one person in the U.S. died to Rubella.
Mumps Post-vaccine: A viral disease that most often afflicts children, Mumps claimed only one American life in 1977, 10 years after the Mumps vaccine was instituted by the government.
Shark: The movie Jaws stereotyped sharks very poorly. Sharks only claimed 10 lives in 2014.
Wolf: Death by being mauled or attacked by wolves is very rare. Only 10 deaths were reported in the year 2014 worldwide, a majority of which were children.
Chicken Pox Post-vaccine: A disease that affects mostly children, chicken pox claimed only 13 lives in 2005, a significant decrease after a vaccine was instituted ten years prior.
Polio Post-vaccine: Ten years after the polio vaccine was discovered, only 20 annual deaths were attributed to polio.
Measles Post-vaccine: In 1973, ten years of the the measles vaccine was introduced, only 23 people in the U.S. died to measles.
Rubella Pre-vaccine: 29 people died as a result of the German Measles in 1969 in America, just one year after the vaccine was introduced.
Mumps Pre-vaccine: 37 people died as a result of Mumps, just before the vaccine was introduced (1967).
Diptheria Post-vaccine: In 1960, ten years after the widespread use of the vaccine, the number of deaths in the U.S. caused by diptheria was 69.
Lion: The King of the Jungle was responsible for 100 human deaths across the world in 2014.
Elephant: Elephants turned out to be almost 10x more deadly than sharks in 2014, claiming 100 lives across the world.
Chicken Pox Pre-vaccine: Just before the vaccine became widespread (1995), Chicken Pox claimed 115 lives in the United States.
Whooping Cough Pre-vaccine: Whooping cough claimed 119 lives in the United States in 1960, just before the vaccie was instituted.
Mining: Mining happens to be one of the world's most dangerous professions. It claimed 122 lives in 2002 and numbers haven't really changed since then.
Tetanus Post-vaccine: Tetanus vaccinations were not offered in many states -- perhaps this is why it claimed 231 lives in 1960, even though the vaccine had existed for 10 years.
Gulf War: The gulf war, also known as Operation Desert Shield, caused the loss of 258 lives.
Tetanus Pre-vaccine: In 1950, at the very start of widespread tetanus vaccination, 336 people in the U.S. died of tetanus.
Measles Pre-vaccine: Measles clainmed 364 U.S. lives in the year 1963, just before the vaccine was instituted.
Hepatitis B Pre-vaccine: Hep B, a particularly painful affliction, killed 395 people in 1981, the year the vaccination was introduced in the United States.
Diptheria Pre-vaccine: In 1960, Diptheria claimed 69 U.S. lives, just after the vaccine was instituted.
Hippopotamus: Known for its hard spelling as opposed to its deathly nature, hippos were responsible for almost 500 human deaths in 2014, more than lions and sharks combined.
Manufacturing: Accidents and miscalculations in blue collar manufacturing industries costed 564 human lives in the year 2002 in the US alone.
Agriculture: Agriculture and Forestry related incidents claimed 790 lives in the last consensus survey in the United States.
Transportation: Accidents and incidents in shipping, trucking and other transportation related activities were responsible for 910 deaths in 2002.

Hep B Post-vaccine: Surprisingly, Hep B deaths went UP in 2002 (912 U.S. deaths) after after the Hep B vaccination was introduced. Scientists have attributed this to a mutation in the string that went unnoticed for a long time.
Crocodile: Crocodiles claimed 1000 lives in different parts of the world in the year 2014
Polio Pre-vaccine: Polio claimed 1043 lives in the US in 1955, the year the Polio Vaccine was introduced into the market.
Whooping Cough Pre-vaccine: 1118 people were killed in 1950, a significantly higher number than after the vaccine was introduced.
Construction: Construction work kiled 1125 people in 2002, one of the deadlier professions
Tornado: In 1989, 1300 people were killed as a result of the Daulatpur-Salturia Tornado - one of the deadliest tornados in history.
column5: Finch, Jonathan. "Tornados in Bangladesh and East India –—". National Weather Service. Bangladesh tornadoes

column4: Tapeworm: The deathly tapeworm, which can grow up to 6 feet long inside its victims killed 2000 people in 2014 alone.
Afghanistan: It's surprising that the War on Drugs in Afghanistan in its entirety has claimed just 344 more people than the Tapeworm in the year 2014 alone: 2344.
Ascaris Roundworm: Roundworm infections which are very hard to cure once in advanced stages, killed 2500 people in 2014.
Terrorist Attacks on US Soil: From 1995-2014, 3264 people in the U.S. died to terrorist attacks (3003 of which occured during the 9/11 attacks).
Gun Violence: Domestic gun violence killed 3664 people in 2015 alone - vote Bernie Sanders!
Blizzards: Blizzards and snowstorms -- and cold in general killed 4000 people in Iran in 1972 - one of the worst cold spells in the history of the Middle East.
Chernobyl: The nuclear fallout in Ukraine in 1986 claimed 4000+ lives when it happened. It also doomed the area for generations to come.
column5: "Chernobyl: the true scale of the accident". WHO. WHO/IAEA/UNDP.

column4: Iraq War: The Iraq War has claimed 4800 American Lives since the year 2003 -- both military and civillian.
Carbon Monoxide Poisioning: Although we're not quite sure how this happens, Carbon Monoxide poisoning claims 5150 odd lives every year.
Malaria: Malaria, caused by the bite of the Anopheles mosquito, kills approximately 8680 people per year in the modern day. No known vaccine exists for malaria.
Tsetse Fly: The Tsetse fly, known to cause sleeping sickness in Africa, kills 10000 people per year, primarily in the Sub-Saharan Region.
Assassin Bug: The Assassin Bug kills 10000 people per year. Truly belongs on Assassin's Creed.
Freshwater Snails: Looks can be deceiving. Physical contact with freshwater snails kill 10,000 people in the world every year.
Homicide: Pre-planned human-on-human violence killed 14,350 people in the United States alone in 2014. We made sure there was as little overlap as possible with gun violence in this case.
Storm: The 1999 Vargas Tragedy killed 15,100 people -- one of the worst storms in histoy.
column5: Wieczorek GF, Larsen MC, Eaton LS, Morgan BA, Blair JL (2 December 2002)."Debris-flow and flooding hazards associated with the December 1999 storm in coastal Venezuela and strategies for mitigation". U.S. Geological Survey.

column4: Avalanche: 1970 Huascarán avalanche; triggered by the 1970 Ancash earthquake, killed 20,000 people. It remains the worst avalanche in human history.
Dog: Man's best friend is responsible for the deaths of 25,000 people worldwide, per year. Poor sharks just get a bad reputation.
American Revolution: 25,000 patriots lost their lives in the quest for freedom, liberty and democracy between 1775 and 1783.
Road Accidents: Road Accidents killed 32,675 pedestrians and drivers in the US alone in 2014.
Korean War: 36,516 American soldiers were killed between 1950-53 in the Korean War.
Suicide: 42,773 lives were lost as a result of self harm in 2015 -- in the United States alone.
Snake: Venomous and Non-venomous snakes killed 50,000 people across the world in 2014.
Vietnam War: Compulsory conscription led to a very poorly fought war. 58,209 lives were lost in Vietnam in the period of 1955-75.
Heat Wave: The 2003 European Heatwave killed 70,000 people all across Europe.
column5: Robine, Jean-Marie; Cheung, Siu Lan K.; Le Roy, Sophie; Van Oyen, Herman; Griffiths, Clare; Michel, Jean-Pierre; Herrmann, François Richard (2008)."Death toll exceeded 70,000 in Europe during the summer of 2003". Comptes Rendus Biologies 331 (2): 171–178.doi:10.1016/j.crvi.2007.12.001. ISSN 1631-0691.PMID 18241810.

column4: Volcanic Erruption: The 1815 eruption of Mount Tambora occured in Indonesia, killing 92,000, making it the deadliest volcanic erruption ever recorded.
column5: USGS account of historical volcanic induced tsunamis. Hvo.wr.usgs.gov.

column4: Influenza and Pneumonia: 93,531 individuals were killed in the United States alone in the year 2014 as a result of Influenza -- a preventable infection.
Measles (Annual): Although numbers in USA have gone down, 114,900 lives were lost to Measles in 2014 across the world because of lack of access to healthcare.
WW1 US Deaths: The First World War saw the loss of 204,000 US lives.
Cyclone: The 1970 Bhola cyclone occured in Bangladesh, killing 375,000, making it the deadliest cyclone ever recorded.
column5: Paula Ouderm (December 6, 2007). "NOAA Researcher's Warning Helps Save Lives in Bangladesh". National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

column4: WW2 US Deaths: The Second World War saw the loss of 405,399 US lives.
Civil War: The fight to eradicate slavery saw the loss of 625,000 American lives between 1861 and 1865.
Mosquito: The mosquito is the deadliest animal that walks the face of the earth. It was responsible for 725,000 deaths in 2014 alone.
Earthquake: 830,000 people lost their lives in the 1556 Shaanxi Earthquake, the worst in history.
column5: International Association of Engineering Geology International Congress. Proceedings. [1990] (1990). ISBN 90-6191-664-X.

column4: Preterm Complication: Poor access to healthcare and prenatal services cost 1.1 million women across the world their lives in the year 2012.
Tuberculosis: Another disease for which a vaccine exists: it killed 1.5 million people across the world in 2014.
HIV/AIDS: In 2013, approximately 1.5 million people died due to HIV/AID, accounting for 2.7% of worldwide deaths that year.
Diarrhoea: In the 2000s, approximately 1.5 million died due to Diarrhoea, witch children as the most affected age group.

column1: Respiratory Infection due to Environment (Air Pollution)
column4: Respiratory Infection due to Environmental Factors: In the 2000s, approximately 1.5 million died due to respiratory infections caused by the environment (mostly pollution).
Measles (Total before vaccine): Before widespread vaccination in 1980, the number of annual deaths due to measles is estimated to be 2.6 million.
Napoleonic Wars: From 1803 to 1815, the Napoleonic Wars were the cause of 4.9 million deaths.
Russian Civil War: During the Russian Civil War (1917-1921), an estimated 6.7 million people died due to the conflict.
Coronary Artery Disease: Coronary artery diease, currently the deadliest disease in the world, caused approximately 7.4 million deaths in 2012.
Cancer: In 2012, about 8.2 million people worldwide died due to some type of cancer.
Holocaust: During the Holocaust (1927-1949), approximately 11 million Jewish and non-Jewish people perished.
An Lushan Rebellion: The An Lushan Rebellion (755-763) against the Tang dynasty resulted in about 21 million deaths.
Mongol Conquests: The Mongol Conquests (1206-1368) spanned much of Asia and Eastern Europe and caused an estimated 35 million deaths.
WW1: The First World War saw the loss of 38 million total lives.
Taiping Rebellion: The Taiping Rebellion agaist the Qing dynasty resulted in about 40 million deaths.
European Colonization: An estimated 55 million indigenous Americans (North and South America) died due to European colonization.
WW2: The Second World War saw the loss of 85 million total lives.
Black Death: One of the deadliest epidemics in human history, the Bubonic plague is estimated to have killed between 75 million and 200 million.
Smallpox: From 1900 to 2000, between 300 million and 500 million people worldwide died due to smallpox.
